awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the fundamental question of how cells regulate the selective uptake of molecules and material from the surrounding environment. Endocytosis is the process by which cells internalize surface components. During endocytosis, a portion of the plasma membrane is pulled into the inside of the cell forming a small, spherical structure known as an endocytic vesicle. This research will investigate the cellular machinery that carries out endocytosis and how it is regulated. This project will support diversity in science and education through training of undergraduate and graduate students, many of whom belong to groups underrepresented in the sciences. Both undergraduate and graduate students in this project will be involved in taking hands-on yeast research, concepts in cellular compartments, and fluorescence microscopy into middle school classrooms. In addition, knowledge gained through this research will be integrated in undergraduate and graduate courses taught by the principal investigator.

This research will explore fundamental and outstanding questions in endocytosis. Aim 1 will tackle one of the ongoing problems in the field: is there an endocytic checkpoint and if so how is it regulated? It will test the hypothesis that binding of integral membrane protein cargo by components of the machinery is a central event in the assembly of the endocytic machinery and address a controversy regarding the function of a scaffolding protein called clathrin in membrane bending at endocytic sites. Aims 2 and 3 will explore the activity of two new regulators of the endocytic machinery recently discovered by this laboratory. Aim 2 will investigate the concept that one of the new endocytic proteins regulates the actin cytoskeleton, which provides force to pull the vesicle into the cell. Aim 3 will test the idea that the second new protein regulates dynamics of the endocytic machinery through ubiquitination-deubiquitination, an important but poorly understood posttranslational modification of endocytic proteins. Additional candidate new proteins of the endocytic machinery will be systematically tested to verify if they indeed work in endocytosis and to understand how they work. The powerful Saccharomyces cerevisiae system will allow for the study of endocytosis regulators both in vivo and in vitro. The research will be multidisciplinary including yeast genetics, live cell fluorescence microscopy, electron microscopy and electron tomography, biochemistry, X-ray protein crystallography, equilibrium binding assays and kinetic assays, as well as modeling approaches.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

 

This project investigated the mechanism by which eukaryotic cells transport molecules and material into the cell. This process is called endocytosis, and it is fundamental for life. For instance, endocytosis is a major way for cells to incorporate nutrients.  In this process a small portion of the cell limiting membrane progressively bends towards the cell interior until it is released as a vesicle, a small membrane bound compartment. Endocytosis proceeds in a well-choreographed manner but little is known about how this tight regulation is achieved. Importantly, endocytosis occurs in a very similar way across eukaryotic species. This project advanced knowledge and understanding of endocytosis regulation using a well-established and technically convenient model system, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the yeast used by bakers and brewers. The following are key project outcomes:

 

(A) The traditional view has been that the cellular machinery driving endocytic vesicle formation assembles on the cell surface first and then the extracellular molecules are bound and packaged into the incipient vesicle. Such model attributes the so-called cargo molecules a passive role in the endocytic process. Our data showed cargo molecules are not passive players, but that they stabilize the machinery at the cell surface and facilitate progression of endocytosis.

 

(B) Clathrin is a scaffolding protein component of the endocytosis machinery typically believed to be important for shaping the endocytic vesicle. However, recent publications had challenged this model leaving clathrin function uncertain. This project provided evidence that (1) Clathrin is in fact required for normal shaping of the endocytic invagination, and (2) such activity is needed for progression of endocytosis.

 

(C) We have discovered a group of novel, uncharacterized candidate protein components of the endocytosis machinery. Here we addressed the function of a subset of these proteins in endocytosis. We found they are new regulators of the actin cytoskeleton, a dynamic structure that provides force to bend the membrane into an invagination and pinch off a vesicle. We found these new proteins define the size and shape of the actin cytoskeleton by capping and limiting its unproductive growth.

 

(D) The project elucidated endocytosis functions for protein families that have been conserved through evolution, the dynein light chain and ubiquitin regulatory proteins. Thus, this research uncovered mechanistic links between endocytosis and other cellular processes previously known to rely on these conserved protein families.    

 

 

Broader impacts

 

Endocytosis regulates myriad cellular activities such as the speed of cell growth and therefore this new knowledge has applications in biotechnology, synthetic biology and beyond. Defects in endocytosis cause a variety of diseases and endocytosis is highjacked by many viruses to enter cells. Thus, understanding endocytosis has implications in health and disease.

 

With regards to training, this project supported 3 PhD students, Kristen Farrell (graduated in 2016), Thomas Tolsma (graduated in 2018) and Andrew Lamb (will defend his Thesis on October 26, 2022). All of them published first author papers and presented their research at the American Society for Cell Biology (ASCB) annual meeting and several other venues. They have received multiple university awards, and Kristen and Thomas received pre-doctoral fellowships from the American Heart Association. Since graduating, Kristen has been working as a postdoctoral Scientist at MBC Pharma and Thomas is a Scientist at BioMarin Pharmaceuticals Inc.

 

Eighteen undergraduate students were supported by this grant. All undergraduates received awards at the university level, state level, and/or national level. Most undergraduate students presented posters at the University level or higher. Several of them (12) are or will be co-authors on papers. All 14 that graduated are currently in graduate school or obtained jobs in which they directly apply the knowledge and training received in our lab. Overall, more than one third of the undergraduate students belong to ethnic minorities underrepresented in the sciences and 60% are females.  

 

Both undergraduate and graduate students were involved in taking hands-on yeast research, concepts in cellular organelles, and fluorescence microscopy into middle school classrooms. Approximately 60 students per year from Lesher Middle School benefited from this outreach program. Additionally, one High School student from a local Charter School, Compass Community Collaborative School, performed significant hands-on research in our laboratory.  

 

The grant supported Dr. Santiago Di Pietro, the only underrepresented minority Faculty in the department.

 

Results from the project were published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at multiple conferences from local and regional symposia to national and international meetings.
